text: well overall I would say it is a message
of hope from tacloban the entire
humanitarian community works here I
think is impressed by the strength of
the people communities and the
government in in rebuilding what was a
devastated place this tremendous amount
of work left to do but given the short
period of time we've had since the
typhoon i think the progress is very
impressive yeah we're looking at
pictures of the devastation that was
calls in the aftermath of when that
typhoon struck in early November still
hundreds of thousands of people are
displaced living in makeshift shelters
we mentioned in our introduction to you
that Christmas is approaching I mean how
are people feeling at the moment well I
think or a deeply religious catholic
country like the Philippines it's a very
important time for the people of taco
bomb and the best way for me to describe
it is to refer to the slogan that the
tax O'Banion's have adopted which is
translated Tacloban will rise again it's
a there's a tremendous sense of relief
for the people who've survived there is
lots of grief for those who lost their
lives there's also tremendous energy to
rebuild an amazing level of gratitude
towards the international community I
have rarely worked in an emergency where
you get thanked so much and so genuinely
by people affected by the disaster on a
daily basis so there's a tremendous
amount of gratitude to the international
community to people like me who do work
here and but most of our gratitude as as
eight workers must go to the people of
Leyte province here they have over they
are overcoming what is a tremendous
disaster but in the spirit of community
and hard work that is a pretty amazing
yeah incredible to hear that from you
and also from the people that we spoken
to on the ground it seems
their resilience I mean they are so
robust but when you look at the months
ahead what for you is the biggest
challenge now in the relief operation
well I think the biggest challenge is to
transition from what is still what I
would say is currently the end of the
real relief phase is into the early
recovery phase and this means a change
of pace a change of ways of working
building on the capacities that
definitely exist but also trying to look
at the vulnerabilities that exist a lot
of people have a lot of livelihoods have
been damaged they will take years to
recover and in a lot of ways we're
trying to build back work with work with
structures work with organizations work
with others in a way that will make this
this area this country more prepared and
less vulnerable to future disasters so
there's a there's a lot of work on
disaster risk reduction and trying to
plan to make people less vulnerable to
natural disaster which will be a feature
of the Philippines for for very long
time to come there was Peter a lot of
criticism at the time level that the
government and local authorities for not
providing enough provisions to the
people that needed it most and taking
precautions when they knew that this
typhoon was approaching how are things
regarding the people in local
authorities now are you getting a sense
that there is a support network around
the people that need it by the
government and their resources
absolutely I think Philippine government
has just presented a master plan for the
for the recovery of this region it the
government coordinates very closely on a
daily basis the City Council coordinates
on a daily basis with the United Nations
with I NGOs the capacity of government
departments of government workers back
at work we knock some work a lot with
with the water district they've done an
amazing job in putting municipal water
supplies back to hundreds of thousands
of people in a short space of time so I
would be hesitant to do level criticism
at at the overall response or or at the
Philippine government
